body:
Example of output:

```
./build.sh --from-release --activemq-version 5.18.2  
Downloading apache-activemq-5.18.2-bin.tar.gz from https://dlcdn.apache.org/activemq/5.18.2/
Using 11 as target Java version
```

```
./build.sh --from-local-dist                                    
Using ActiveMQ dist: ../../target/apache-activemq-*.tar.gz
Using 17 as target Java version
```

```
 ./build.sh --from-local-dist --target-java-version 11
Using ActiveMQ dist: ../../target/apache-activemq-*.tar.gz
Using 11 as target Java version
```
Thanks I gonna take a look. But I think we can do that in a easy way: as the Java version is specific to a branch, we can have specified in the dockerfile.

Just note that even if the folder is duplicated in each branch, if in branch 5.19, I execute `./build.sh --from-release --activemq-version 5.18.2`, the Java version will be 17 while the expected version is still 11.
In other words, the flexibility of the script can have side effects if the target Java version is not fully managed.
Ok, I reverted the proposal, let's wait for 5.19

Yeah, image names change too much. I don't think we can rely on a a simple '11', '17' parameter.

Perhaps we should move the full container image name up to the parent pom right next to JDK version, so we can remember to update them at the same time.

I propose to do the following change:
- one specific `Dockerfile` per branch, specific for the branch (JDK version but we could also have some jetty options, etc)
- square the `--release-version` arg in the `build.sh` to allow only minor version on the major version of the branch

Easier to maintain and more logical IMHO.

To summarize:
1. I will merge this PR on `main` branch as the target is 5.19.x for JDK 17
2. I will do another change to update the `--release-version` option to square the version to the branch version
3. I keep JDK 11 (temurin) on `activemq-5.18.x` with the same change for `--release-version`option
@jbonofre Maybe you are a bit more active and could check this PR.
Sure thing ! I will. Thanks !

`poms` are not enough IMHO. `Jenkinsfile` should be updated too.

I proposed to do it on the mailing list, please can I take it ?
Is the plan to try and get this into 6.0.0 or for 6.1.0?

> @cshannon Yes, I was looking to get it into 6.0.0/5.18.NEXT
> 
> The change is minor (all wrapper, no functional).
> 
> Thoughts?

Yeah that's fine I wasn't sure how soon we were planning to release and just didn't want to put anything in last second but there should be time
I think this wrapper is great for 6.0.0 and next 5.18.x. Thanks !
@mattrpav @cshannon Hello there, any idea when these changes will be released?

@jbonofre @cshannon 

This is what is working w/ this PR:
1. JMX, Jetty and ActiveMQ use a shared JAAS login realm

TODO:
1. To achieve JMX, activemq-run needed to be shaded w/ slf4j-api which mixes up log bootstrapping. Either we convert activemq-jaas to use jul, or bootstrap slf4j logging in activemq-run
2. Jetty has some path spec stuff not working correctly for web authz

Background-- JMX can use JAAS, but that means it class-for-name instantiates the LoginConfig and uses the *Principal classes from activemq-jaas. Any dependency used in activemq-jaas needs to be available at boot time (ie. activemq-run).

Can this wait until 6.1.0? The issue has been open for a while and doesn't seem like it would be a big deal if it was done in 6.1.0

I took a quick look but i am not familiar with any of the stuff here and i would need more time than i have this week likely to look into it if you need help fixing it and i know we were trying to get 6.0.0 out soon
And I should add it's still fine to go into 6.0.0 if it can be figured out this week, I just didn't want to hold things up for a long time because of it.

Overall my impressions are that this seems more complicated than it appears to be at first glance because you need to properly handle rolling things back and making sure that in certain modes the client acts like the receive was never called. I am not sure that simply re-adding the message to the unconsumed list is enough. There's a lot of code in rollback() to handle things like duplicate detection so the message can be received again.

So that being said I think this needs more work and a lot more testing and might need to wait for 6.1.0
Well the main problem with the logging issue is people use slf4j and not JUL. If you converted then it breaks logging under other use cases?

We ship a conf/logging.properties already today. So we can document that JAAS logging is different, or install the jul-to-slf4j bridge.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9117030/jul-to-slf4j-bridge

I think JAAS logging being separate isn't a huge deal (and doesn't change audit). activemq-jaas logging is about debugging things like LDAP connectivity, etc-- things that have been super stable for a long time.

The main problem with the bridge is the performance penalty so I wouldn't include it. If you read the documentation there can be a pretty big performance penalty so i don't know that we would want to include it by default, not sure. So probably just make it JUL and let other people decide if they want to add a bridge.

I agree this kind of change is acceptable in 6.0.0. If we don't include in 6.0.0, then, we will have to wait 7.0.0 because it's a huge major change for the users: the user/password file will completely different, etc.

About logging, I don't think it's a major concern. For instance, I know a lot of users using jetty-jaas/jetty-ldap and they struggled to have log messages in `activemq.log` due to the backend (jetty using JUL). The performance impact is "limited" imho as we talk about log from specific areas. 

I would also test that we can use different realms per scope: one for broker, one for jetty, one for JMX. Most of our users are using different authentication backend (at least between broker and jetty/admin console).

So, if we want to include in 6.0.0, I would:
1. do large tests (manual) with multiple realms, different login modules
2. according to (1), it needs time. I would rather see that change in 7.0.0 and document (on website) how to secure the JMX and admin console (it's already what we do with 5.x).

Proposal:

1. Include in v6.0.0 (this is a makes-life-easier-for-new users feature)
2. [DONE] Add example configs for how to separate the realms back out into the dist assembly
3. [DONE] Convert activemq-jaas to jul
4. Update website w/ logging for activemq-jaas and how to use the breakout-realm configs

I agree with the proposal. I just add (for me):

5. Extensive tests with different realms (for broker, jetty/adminconsole and JMX) and login modules (LDAP, JDBC, ...), including eventually unit tests
Fully agree, it's definitely a good idea.
@mattrpav Hi, is there a roadmap when `5.19.x` containing this PR will be available? Thanks!
@aeberhardo it's not `5.19.x` but actually the next ActiveMQ release planned is `6.0.0` (including this change and others). The target date for the vote is end of this week/beginning of next week.

hi @jbonofre 
I read in ActiveMQ Artemis Page (https://activemq.apache.org/how-does-activemq-compare-to-artemis) that the next activemq 6 would be the Artemis version. So, will the 6.0.0 that you mentioned, be the Artemis?

No that's not the case anymore (the website should be updated): we discussed on the mailing list to keep on our ActiveMQ versioning. 

So ActiveMQ 6.0.0 will be ActiveMQ (not Artemis). I will update the website.

I already noticed two potential issues to address:
1. web console authentication seems to not work out of the box (I will double check)
2. jolokia authentication seems also broken

I'm fixing that.
@jbonofre jolokia is removed altogether since it doesn't support Jakarta (yet).
@mattrpav that's my point, we have to document/state that on website/Release Notes. It's a breaking change.
I'm testing now

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
I'm testing a change on Karaf features to work smoothly. If needed I will create another PR based on this one. Thanks.
About Jolokia, I think it would be better to upgrade to Jolokia 2.0.0-M4 which support Jakarta Servlet API. I'm on it.

I understand the differences with the authentication on the web console, I simply believed that it is what the OP was expecting. I guess the OP needs to clarify a bit more because it is really unclear/misleading
Agree, the ticket should provide some details. However, I think it would be acceptable to have different env variables, depending what kind of credentials we want to provide.
Superseeded by #1074 1074
Closing old PRs.

IMHO, it should be better to have an http option to support openwire format. Something like:

```
  <transportConnector name="http" uri="http://0.0.0.0:1234?openwireSerializatrionEnabled=true" />
```

It would allow to support current marshalling and openwire marshalling.

NB: if you don't reply to this PR quickly, this one will be closed.
I'm not able to reproduce it. I think it has been already resolved as `entryLocator` doesn't seem to be null.
Closing old PRs.
Disabling transaction does the trick. Closing old PR.

The Jenkins execution failed as there's no space left on the executor.
I will test locally on my machine. If you want, you can trigger a new build (creating an empty commit and rebasing for instance).

Yeah, regarding the change, I don't expect any issue :)
I can't get CI to run so I will just merge it and we can let CI run whenever it works again against main

The change looks good to me. I think using `firstMessageTimestamp` is good. However, I would also add `lastMessageTimestamp`.

I propose to enable this when fully moving to GitHub Action.

It would be great to provide some explanation about this change:
1. why using `decrypt` on properties to get the password. My understanding is that you are using encrypted password (instead of plain)
2. If you are using encrypted password, the JAAS plugin should be configured by a property to define if the password is encrypted or not, else I think it will break all users using plain password.
I added milestone on GH to indicate the target version for PR. This one is targeted for 6.1.0 (updated the Jira too).

Superseded by #1114

While activemq-client-jakarta is a relocation to 6.0.0, the way the camel-activemq pulls it in, Maven reactor isn't up-leveling it to 6.0.0 for us-- which would have made this a non-issue. Alas, we'll need to recut the release.

I see activemq BOM's in our future.

% mvn dependency:tree snippet
```
[INFO] +- org.apache.camel:camel-activemq:jar:4.1.0:compile
[INFO] |  \- org.apache.activemq:activemq-client-jakarta:jar:5.18.2:compile
```
I can merge this and then we need to revert the 6.0.0 preparation on the main branch and redo the release, I will let @jbonofre handle that.

I had to add it because the user passed by environment variable ACTIVEMQ_WEB_USER (and its password) was not  having any effect when accessing the web console, as the configuration file jetty.xml points to jetty-realm.properties and not to the file which the sed command was modifying...

`    <bean id="securityLoginService" class="org.eclipse.jetty.security.HashLoginService">
        <property name="name" value="ActiveMQRealm" />
        <property name="config" value="${activemq.conf}/jetty-realm.properties" />
    </bean>
`
I dont need separate access, I just need to change the default user and password. Should I do something different?
@lionelraymundi you should take a look on the `Dockerfile` from `activemq-5.18.x` branch.

Hi, 

I met an issue when using Nondex, a tool for detecting and debugging wrong assumptions on under-determined Java APIs. (https://github.com/TestingResearchIllinois/NonDex) When I run the detect flakiness command on the AMQ9255Test, sometimes I will get this error:
`[ERROR] Errors: 
[ERROR]   AMQ9255Test.testExpiredMessages:146  JMS Could not post command: MessageAck {commandId = 5, responseRequired = false, ackType = 2, consumerId = ID:fa23-cs527-073.cs.illinois.edu-37869-1700429033032-5:2:1:1, firstMessageId = ID:fa23-cs527-073.cs.illinois.edu-37869-1700429033032-5:1:1:1:1, lastMessageId = ID:fa23-cs527-073.cs.illinois.edu-37869-1700429033032-5:1:1:1:1, destination = queue://ActiveMQ.DLQ, transactionId = null, messageCount = 1, poisonCause = null} due to: org.apache.http.NoHttpResponseException: localhost:8161 failed to respond
[INFO] 
[ERROR] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0`

This error won't appear everytime, but just sometimes. Did you have an idea where the problem is? Thank you in advance.
